text: Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: which he promised beforehand through his prophets in the holy scriptures,
speaker: Narrator

text: the gospel concerning his Son, who was descended from David according to the flesh
speaker: Narrator

text: and was declared to be Son of God with power according to the spirit of holiness by resurrection from the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: through whom we have received grace and apostleship to bring about the obedience of faith among all the gentiles for the sake of his name,
speaker: Narrator

text: including you who are called to belong to Jesus Christ,
speaker: Narrator

text:
To all God’s beloved in Rome, who are called to be saints:
Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith is proclaimed throughout the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God, whom I serve with my spirit by announcing the gospel of his Son, is my witness that without ceasing I remember you always in my prayers,
speaker: Narrator

text: asking that by God’s will I may somehow at last succeed in coming to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I long to see you so that I may share with you some spiritual gift so that you may be strengthened—
speaker: Narrator

text: or rather so that we may be mutually encouraged by each other’s faith, both yours and mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not want you to be unaware, brothers and sisters, that I have often intended to come to you (but thus far have been prevented), in order that I may reap some harvest among you, as I have among the rest of the gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am obligated both to Greeks and to barbarians, both to the wise and to the foolish,
speaker: Narrator

text: hence my eagerness to proclaim the gospel to you also who are in Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel; it is God’s saving power for everyone who believes, for the Jew first and also for the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed through faith for faith, as it is written, “The one who is righteous will live by faith.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and injustice of those who by their injustice suppress the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what can be known about God is plain to them, because God has made it plain to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ever since the creation of the world God’s eternal power and divine nature, invisible though they are, have been seen and understood through the things God has made. So they are without excuse,
speaker: Narrator

text: for though they knew God, they did not honor him as God or give thanks to him, but they became futile in their thinking, and their senseless hearts were darkened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Claiming to be wise, they became fools,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling a mortal human or birds or four-footed animals or reptiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore God gave them over in the desires of their hearts to impurity, to the dishonoring of their bodies among themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They exchanged the truth about God for a lie and worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason God gave them over to dishonorable passions. Their females exchanged natural intercourse for unnatural,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the same way also the males, giving up natural intercourse with females, were consumed with their passionate desires for one another. Males committed shameless acts with males and received in their own persons the due penalty for their error.
speaker: Narrator

text: And since they did not see fit to acknowledge God, God gave them over to an unfit mind and to do things that should not be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were filled with every kind of injustice, evil, covetousness, malice. Full of envy, murder, strife, deceit, craftiness, they are gossips,
speaker: Narrator

text: slanderers, God-haters, insolent, haughty, boastful, inventors of evil, rebellious toward parents,
speaker: Narrator

text: foolish, faithless, heartless, ruthless.
speaker: Narrator

text: They know God’s decree, that those who practice such things deserve to die, yet they not only do them but even applaud others who practice them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you are without excuse, whoever you are, when you judge others, for in passing judgment on another you condemn yourself, because you, the judge, are doing the very same things.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that God’s judgment on those who do such things is in accordance with truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you imagine, whoever you are, that when you judge those who do such things and yet do them yourself, you will escape the judgment of God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you despise the riches of his kindness and forbearance and patience? Do you not realize that God’s kindness is meant to lead you to repentance?
speaker: Narrator

text: But by your hard and impenitent heart you are storing up wrath for yourself on the day of wrath, when God’s righteous judgment will be revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will repay according to each one’s deeds:
speaker: Narrator

text: to those who by patiently doing good seek for glory and honor and immortality, he will give eternal life,
speaker: Narrator

text: while for those who are self-seeking and who obey not the truth but injustice, there will be wrath and fury.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be affliction and distress for everyone who does evil, both the Jew first and the Greek,
speaker: Narrator

text: but glory and honor and peace for everyone who does good, both the Jew first and the Greek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God shows no partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who have sinned apart from the law will also perish apart from the law, and all who have sinned under the law will be judged in accordance with the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is not the hearers of the law who are righteous in God’s sight but the doers of the law who will be justified.
speaker: Narrator

text: When gentiles, who do not possess the law, by nature do what the law requires, these, though not having the law, are a law to themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: They show that what the law requires is written on their hearts, as their own conscience also bears witness, and their conflicting thoughts will accuse or perhaps excuse them
speaker: Narrator

text: on the day when, according to my gospel, God through Christ Jesus judges the secret thoughts of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you call yourself a Jew and rely on the law and boast of your relation to God
speaker: Narrator

text: and know his will and determine what really matters because you are instructed in the law,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you are sure that you are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text: a corrector of the foolish, a teacher of children, having in the law the embodiment of knowledge and truth,
speaker: Narrator

text: you, then, who teach others, will you not teach yourself? You who preach against stealing, do you steal?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who forbid adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?
speaker: Narrator

text: You who boast in the law, do you dishonor God by your transgression of the law?
speaker: Narrator

text: For, as it is written, “The name of God is blasphemed among the gentiles because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Circumcision indeed is of value if you obey the law, but if you are a transgressor of the law your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, if the uncircumcised keep the requirements of the law, will not their uncircumcision be regarded as circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the physically uncircumcised person who keeps the law will judge you who, though having the written code and circumcision, are a transgressor of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a person is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is circumcision something external and physical.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, a person is a Jew who is one inwardly, and circumcision is a matter of the heart, by the Spirit, not the written code. Such a person receives praise not from humans but from God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what advantage has the Jew? Or what is the value of circumcision?
speaker: Narrator

text: Much, in every way. For in the first place, the Jews were entrusted with the oracles of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: What if some were unfaithful? Will their faithlessness nullify the faithfulness of God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
By no means! Although every human is a liar, let God be proved true, as it is written,
“So that you may be justified in your words
    and you will prevail when you go to trial.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But if our injustice serves to confirm the justice of God, what should we say? That God is unjust to inflict wrath on us? (I speak in a human way.)
speaker: Narrator

text: By no means! For then how could God judge the world?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if through my falsehood God’s truthfulness abounds to his glory, why am I still being judged as a sinner?
speaker: Narrator

text: And why not say (as some people slander us by saying that we say), “Let us do evil so that good may come”? Their judgment is deserved!
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Are we any better off? No, not at all, for we have already charged that all, both Jews and Greeks, are under the power of sin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as it is written:
“There is no one who is righteous, not even one;
speaker: Narrator

text:
there is no one who has understanding;
        there is no one who seeks God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: “Their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Their feet are swift to shed blood;
speaker: Narrator

text: ruin and misery are in their paths,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the way of peace they have not known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “There is no fear of God before their eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now we know that, whatever the law says, it speaks to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the whole world may be held accountable to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no human will be justified before him by deeds prescribed by the law, for through the law comes the knowledge of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, apart from the law, the righteousness of God has been disclosed and is attested by the Law and the Prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: the righteousness of God through the faith of Jesus Christ for all who believe. For there is no distinction,
speaker: Narrator

text: since all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God;
speaker: Narrator

text: they are now justified by his grace as a gift, through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom God put forward as a sacrifice of atonement by his blood, effective through faith. He did this to demonstrate his righteousness, because in his divine forbearance he had passed over the sins previously committed;
speaker: Narrator

text: it was to demonstrate at the present time his own righteousness, so that he is righteous and he justifies the one who has the faith of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then what becomes of boasting? It is excluded. Through what kind of law? That of works? No, rather through the law of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we hold that a person is justified by faith apart from works prescribed by the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or is God the God of Jews only? Is he not the God of gentiles also? Yes, of gentiles also,
speaker: Narrator

text: since God is one, and he will justify the circumcised on the ground of faith and the uncircumcised through that same faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do we then overthrow the law through this faith? By no means! On the contrary, we uphold the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say was gained by Abraham, our ancestor according to the flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about, but not before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For what does the scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was reckoned to him as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to one who works, wages are not reckoned as a gift but as something due.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to one who does not work but trusts him who justifies the ungodly, such faith is reckoned as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also David pronounces a blessing on those to whom God reckons righteousness apart from works:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven
    and whose sins are covered;
speaker: Narrator

text: blessed is the one against whom the Lord will not reckon sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this blessing, then, pronounced only on the circumcised or also on the uncircumcised? We say, “Faith was reckoned to Abraham as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: How then was it reckoned to him? Was it before or after he had been circumcised? It was not after but before he was circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: He received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised. The purpose was to make him the ancestor of all who believe without being circumcised and who thus have righteousness reckoned to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and likewise the ancestor of the circumcised who are not only circumcised but follow the example of the faith that our ancestor Abraham had before he was circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the promise that he would inherit the world did not come to Abraham or to his descendants through the law but through the righteousness of faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if it is the adherents of the law who are to be the heirs, faith is null and the promise is void.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law brings wrath, but where there is no law, neither is there transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason the promise depends on faith, in order that it may rest on grace, so that it may be guaranteed to all his descendants, not only to the adherents of the law but also to those who share the faith of Abraham (who is the father of all of us,
speaker: Narrator

text: as it is written, “I have made you the father of many nations”), in the presence of the God in whom he believed, who gives life to the dead and calls into existence the things that do not exist.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hoping against hope, he believed that he would become “the father of many nations,” according to what was said, “So shall your descendants be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not weaken in faith when he considered his own body, which was already as good as dead (for he was about a hundred years old), and the barrenness of Sarah’s womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: No distrust made him waver concerning the promise of God, but he grew strong in his faith as he gave glory to God,
speaker: Narrator

text: being fully convinced that God was able to do what he had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore “it was reckoned to him as righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the words, “it was reckoned to him,” were written not for his sake alone
speaker: Narrator

text: but for ours also. It will be reckoned to us who believe in him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was handed over for our trespasses and was raised for our justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, since we are justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
speaker: Narrator

text: through whom we have obtained access to this grace in which we stand, and we boast in our hope of sharing the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And not only that, but we also boast in our afflictions, knowing that affliction produces endurance,
speaker: Narrator

text: and endurance produces character, and character produces hope,
speaker: Narrator

text: and hope does not put us to shame, because God’s love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit that has been given to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, rarely will anyone die for a righteous person—though perhaps for a good person someone might actually dare to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God proves his love for us in that while we still were sinners Christ died for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Much more surely, therefore, since we have now been justified by his blood, will we be saved through him from the wrath of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, much more surely, having been reconciled, will we be saved by his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But more than that, we even boast in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and death came through sin, and so death spread to all because all have sinned—
speaker: Narrator

text: for sin was indeed in the world before the law, but sin is not reckoned when there is no law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who did not sin in the likeness of Adam, who is a pattern of the one who was to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the free gift is not like the trespass. For if the many died through the one man’s trespass, much more surely have the grace of God and the gift in the grace of the one man, Jesus Christ, abounded for the many.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the gift is not like the effect of the one man’s sin. For the judgment following one trespass brought condemnation, but the gift following many trespasses brings justification.
speaker: Narrator

text: If, because of the one man’s trespass, death reigned through that one, much more surely will those who receive the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one man, Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore just as one man’s trespass led to condemnation for all, so one man’s act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all.
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as through the one man’s disobedience the many were made sinners, so through the one man’s obedience the many will be made righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: But law came in, so that the trespass might increase, but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that, just as sin reigned in death, so grace might also reign through justification leading to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say? Should we continue in sin in order that grace may increase?
speaker: Narrator

text: By no means! How can we who died to sin go on living in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that all of us who were baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so we also might walk in newness of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we have been united with him in a death like his, we will certainly be united with him in a resurrection like his.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that our old self was crucified with him so that the body of sin might be destroyed, so we might no longer be enslaved to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever has died is freed from sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that Christ, being raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has dominion over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The death he died, he died to sin once for all, but the life he lives, he lives to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal bodies, so that you obey their desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer present your members to sin as instruments of unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as those who have been brought from death to life, and present your members to God as instruments of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin will have no dominion over you, since you are not under law but under grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Should we sin because we are not under law but under grace? By no means!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not know that, if you present yourselves to anyone as obedient slaves, you are slaves of the one whom you obey, either of sin, which leads to death, or of obedience, which leads to righteousness?
speaker: Narrator

text: But thanks be to God that you who were slaves of sin have become obedient from the heart to the form of teaching to which you were entrusted
speaker: Narrator

text: and that you, having been set free from sin, have become enslaved to righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am speaking in human terms because of your limitations. For just as you once presented your members as slaves to impurity and lawlessness, leading to even more lawlessness, so now present your members as slaves to righteousness, leading to sanctification.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you were slaves of sin, you were free in regard to righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: So what fruit did you then gain from the things of which you now are ashamed? The end of those things is death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now that you have been freed from sin and enslaved to God, the fruit you have leads to sanctification, and the end is eternal life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you not know, brothers and sisters—for I am speaking to those who know the law—that the law is binding on a person only during that person’s lifetime?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus a married woman is bound by the law to her husband as long as he lives, but if her husband dies, she is discharged from the law concerning the husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: Accordingly, she will be called an adulteress if she belongs to another man while her husband is alive. But if her husband dies, she is free from that law, and if she belongs to another man, she is not an adulteress.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, my brothers and sisters, you have died to the law through the body of Christ, so that you may belong to another, to him who was raised from the dead in order that we may bear fruit for God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For while we were living in the flesh, our sinful passions, aroused by the law, were at work in our members to bear fruit for death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now we are discharged from the law, dead to that which held us captive, so that we are enslaved in the newness of the Spirit and not in the oldness of the written code.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say? That the law is sin? By no means! Yet, if it had not been for the law, I would not have known sin. I would not have known what it is to covet if the law had not said, “You shall not covet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But sin, seizing an opportunity through the commandment, produced in me all kinds of covetousness. For apart from the law sin lies dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was once alive apart from the law, but when the commandment came, sin revived
speaker: Narrator

text: and I died, and the very commandment that promised life proved to be death to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sin, seizing an opportunity in the commandment, deceived me and through it killed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the law is holy, and the commandment is holy and just and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Did what is good, then, bring death to me? By no means! It was sin that was working death in me through what is good, in order that it might be shown to be sin, so that through the commandment sin might become sinful beyond measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know that the law is spiritual, but I am of the flesh, sold into slavery under sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: I do not understand my own actions. For I do not do what I want, but I do the very thing I hate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if I do what I do not want, I agree that the law is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in fact it is no longer I who do it but sin that dwells within me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know that the good does not dwell within me, that is, in my flesh. For the desire to do the good lies close at hand, but not the ability.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I do not do the good I want, but the evil I do not want is what I do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if I do what I do not want, it is no longer I who do it but sin that dwells within me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I find it to be a law that, when I want to do what is good, evil lies close at hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I delight in the law of God in my inmost self,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I see in my members another law at war with the law of my mind, making me captive to the law of sin that dwells in my members.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wretched person that I am! Who will rescue me from this body of death?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord!
So then, with my mind I am enslaved to the law of God, but with my flesh I am enslaved to the law of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set you free from the law of sin and of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God has done what the law, weakened by the flesh, could not do: by sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and to deal with sin, he condemned sin in the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the just requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who live according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit set their minds on the things of the Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: To set the mind on the flesh is death, but to set the mind on the Spirit is life and peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason the mind that is set on the flesh is hostile to God; it does not submit to God’s law—indeed, it cannot,
speaker: Narrator

text: and those who are in the flesh cannot please God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you are not in the flesh; you are in the Spirit, since the Spirit of God dwells in you. Anyone who does not have the Spirit of Christ does not belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if Christ is in you, then the body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, he who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will give life to your mortal bodies also through his Spirit that dwells in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, brothers and sisters, we are obligated, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh—
speaker: Narrator

text: for if you live according to the flesh, you will die, but if by the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all who are led by the Spirit of God are children of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you did not receive a spirit of slavery to fall back into fear, but you received a spirit of adoption. When we cry, “Abba! Father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: it is that very Spirit bearing witness with our spirit that we are children of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if children, then heirs: heirs of God and joint heirs with Christ, if we in fact suffer with him so that we may also be glorified with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worth comparing with the glory about to be revealed to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the creation waits with eager longing for the revealing of the children of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the creation was subjected to futility, not of its own will, but by the will of the one who subjected it, in hope
speaker: Narrator

text: that the creation itself will be set free from its enslavement to decay and will obtain the freedom of the glory of the children of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that the whole creation has been groaning together as it suffers together the pains of labor,
speaker: Narrator

text: and not only the creation, but we ourselves, who have the first fruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly while we wait for adoption, the redemption of our bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in hope we were saved. Now hope that is seen is not hope, for who hopes for what one already sees?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we hope for what we do not see, we wait for it with patience.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise the Spirit helps us in our weakness, for we do not know how to pray as we ought, but that very Spirit intercedes with groanings too deep for words.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God, who searches hearts, knows what is the mind of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes for the saints according to the will of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: We know that all things work together for good for those who love God, who are called according to his purpose.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, in order that he might be the firstborn within a large family.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those whom he predestined he also called, and those whom he called he also justified, and those whom he justified he also glorified.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say about these things? If God is for us, who is against us?
speaker: Narrator

text: He who did not withhold his own Son but gave him up for all of us, how will he not with him also give us everything else?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will bring any charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is to condemn? It is Christ who died, or rather, who was raised, who is also at the right hand of God, who also intercedes for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Will affliction or distress or persecution or famine or nakedness or peril or sword?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: No, in all these things we are more than victorious through him who loved us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am convinced that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor rulers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor height, nor depth, nor anything else in all creation will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am speaking the truth in Christ—I am not lying; my conscience confirms it by the Holy Spirit—
speaker: Narrator

text: I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I could wish that I myself were accursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my own brothers and sisters, my own flesh and blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are Israelites, and to them belong the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the worship, and the promises;
speaker: Narrator

text: to them belong the patriarchs, and from them, according to the flesh, comes the Christ, who is over all, God blessed forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not as though the word of God has failed. For not all those descended from Israel are Israelites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and not all of Abraham’s children are his descendants, but “it is through Isaac that descendants shall be named for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This means that it is not the children of the flesh who are the children of God, but the children of the promise are counted as descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of the promise is this: “About this time I will return, and Sarah shall have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor is that all; something similar happened to Rebecca when she had conceived children by one husband, our ancestor Isaac:
speaker: Narrator

text: even before they had been born or had done anything good or bad (so that God’s purpose of election might continue,
speaker: Narrator

text: not by works but by his call) she was told, “The elder shall serve the younger.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As it is written,
“I have loved Jacob,
    but I have hated Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say? Is there injustice on God’s part? By no means!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he says to Moses,
“I will have mercy on whom I have mercy,
    and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it depends not on human will or exertion but on God who shows mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the scripture says to Pharaoh, “I have raised you up for this very purpose, that I may show my power in you and that my name may be proclaimed in all the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then he has mercy on whomever he chooses, and he hardens the heart of whomever he chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say to me then, “Why then does he still find fault? For who can resist his will?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But who indeed are you, a human, to argue with God? Will what is molded say to the one who molds it, “Why have you made me like this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Has the potter no right over the clay, to make out of the same lump one object for special use and another for ordinary use?
speaker: Narrator

text: What if God, desiring to show his wrath and to make known his power, has endured with much patience the objects of wrath that are made for destruction,
speaker: Narrator

text: and what if he has done so in order to make known the riches of his glory for the objects of mercy, which he has prepared beforehand for glory—
speaker: Narrator

text: including us whom he has called, not from the Jews only but also from the gentiles?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As he also says in Hosea,
“Those who were not my people I will call ‘my people,’
    and her who was not beloved I will call ‘beloved.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And in the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’
    there they shall be called children of the living God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah cries out concerning Israel, “Though the number of the children of Israel were like the sand of the sea, only a remnant of them will be saved,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord will execute his sentence on the earth quickly and decisively.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And as Isaiah predicted,
“If the Lord of hosts had not left descendants to us,
    we would have fared like Sodom
    and been made like Gomorrah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What then are we to say? Gentiles, who did not strive for righteousness, have attained it, that is, righteousness through faith,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Israel, who did strive for the law of righteousness, did not attain that law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why not? Because they did not strive for it on the basis of faith but as if it were based on works. They have stumbled over the stumbling stone,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as it is written,
“See, I am laying in Zion a stone that will make people stumble, a rock that will make them fall,
    and whoever trusts in him will not be put to shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Brothers and sisters, my heart’s desire and prayer to God for them is that they may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I can testify that they have a zeal for God, but it is not based on knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not knowing the righteousness of God and seeking to establish their own, they have not submitted to God’s righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ is the culmination of the law so that there may be righteousness for everyone who believes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses writes concerning the righteousness that comes from the law, that “the person who does these things will live by them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the righteousness that comes from faith says, “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’ ” (that is, to bring Christ down)
speaker: Narrator

text: “or ‘Who will descend into the abyss?’ ” (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead).
speaker: Narrator

text:
But what does it say?
“The word is near you,
    in your mouth and in your heart”
(that is, the word of faith that we proclaim),
speaker: Narrator

text: because if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: For one believes with the heart, leading to righteousness, and one confesses with the mouth, leading to salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The scripture says, “No one who believes in him will be put to shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek; the same Lord is Lord of all and is generous to all who call on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord shall be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But how are they to call on one in whom they have not believed? And how are they to believe in one of whom they have never heard? And how are they to hear without someone to proclaim him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And how are they to proclaim him unless they are sent? As it is written, “How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But not all have obeyed the good news, for Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed our message?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So faith comes from what is heard, and what is heard comes through the word of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I ask, have they not heard? Indeed they have:
“Their voice has gone out to all the earth
    and their words to the ends of the world.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text: But of Israel he says, “All day long I have held out my hands to a disobedient and contrary people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I ask, then, has God rejected his people? By no means! I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, a member of the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: God has not rejected his people whom he foreknew. Do you not know what the scripture says of Elijah, how he pleads with God against Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lord, they have killed your prophets, they have demolished your altars; I alone am left, and they are seeking my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But what is the divine reply to him? “I have kept for myself seven thousand who have not bowed the knee to Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So, too, at the present time there is a remnant chosen by grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works, otherwise grace would no longer be grace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What then? Israel has not achieved what it was pursuing. The elect have achieved it, but the rest were hardened,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as it is written,
“God gave them a sluggish spirit,
    eyes that would not see
    and ears that would not hear,
down to this very day.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
let their eyes be darkened so that they cannot see,
    and keep their backs forever bent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I ask, have they stumbled so as to fall? By no means! But through their stumbling salvation has come to the gentiles, so as to make Israel jealous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if their stumbling means riches for the world and if their loss means riches for gentiles, how much more will their full inclusion mean!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I am speaking to you gentiles. Inasmuch as I am an apostle to the gentiles, I celebrate my ministry
speaker: Narrator

text: in order to make my own people jealous and thus save some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if their rejection is the reconciliation of the world, what will their acceptance be but life from the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the part of the dough offered as first fruits is holy, then the whole batch is holy; and if the root is holy, then the branches also are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, a wild olive shoot, were grafted among the others to share the rich root of the olive tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: do not boast over the branches. If you do boast, remember: you do not support the root, but the root supports you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say, “Branches were broken off so that I might be grafted in.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That is true. They were broken off on account of unbelief, but you stand on account of belief. So do not become arrogant, but be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will he spare you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Note then the kindness and the severity of God: severity toward those who have fallen but God’s kindness toward you, if you continue in his kindness; otherwise you also will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And even those of Israel, if they do not continue in unbelief, will be grafted in, for God has the power to graft them in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you have been cut from what is by nature a wild olive tree and grafted, contrary to nature, into a cultivated olive tree, how much more will these natural branches be grafted back into their own olive tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: I want you to understand this mystery, brothers and sisters, so that you may not claim to be wiser than you are: a hardening has come upon part of Israel until the full number of the gentiles has come in.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“And this is my covenant with them,
    when I take away their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As regards the gospel they are enemies for your sake, but as regards election they are beloved for the sake of their ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the gifts and the calling of God are irrevocable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as you were once disobedient to God but have now received mercy because of their disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text: so also they have now been disobedient in order that, by the mercy shown to you, they also may now receive mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God has imprisoned all in disobedience so that he may be merciful to all.
speaker: Narrator

text: O the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments and how inscrutable his ways!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For who has known the mind of the Lord?
    Or who has been his counselor?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or who has given a gift to him,
    to receive a gift in return?”
speaker: Narrator

text: For from him and through him and to him are all things. To him be the glory forever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeal to you therefore, brothers and sisters, on the basis of God’s mercy, to present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God, which is your reasonable act of worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be conformed to this age, but be transformed by the renewing of the mind, so that you may discern what is the will of God—what is good and acceptable and perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by the grace given to me I say to everyone among you not to think of yourself more highly than you ought to think but to think with sober judgment, each according to the measure of faith that God has assigned.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as in one body we have many members and not all the members have the same function,
speaker: Narrator

text: so we, who are many, are one body in Christ, and individually we are members one of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have gifts that differ according to the grace given to us: prophecy, in proportion to faith;
speaker: Narrator

text: ministry, in ministering; the teacher, in teaching;
speaker: Narrator

text: the encourager, in encouragement; the giver, in sincerity; the leader, in diligence; the compassionate, in cheerfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let love be genuine; hate what is evil; hold fast to what is good;
speaker: Narrator

text: love one another with mutual affection; outdo one another in showing honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not lag in zeal; be ardent in spirit; serve the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice in hope; be patient in affliction; persevere in prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Contribute to the needs of the saints; pursue hospitality to strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice with those who rejoice; weep with those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live in harmony with one another; do not be arrogant, but associate with the lowly; do not claim to be wiser than you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not repay anyone evil for evil, but take thought for what is noble in the sight of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is possible, so far as it depends on you, live peaceably with all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beloved, never avenge yourselves, but leave room for the wrath of God, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine; I will repay, says the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, “if your enemies are hungry, feed them; if they are thirsty, give them something to drink, for by doing this you will heap burning coals on their heads.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let every person be subject to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except from God, and those authorities that exist have been instituted by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore whoever resists authority resists what God has appointed, and those who resist will incur judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: For rulers are not a terror to good conduct but to bad. Do you wish to have no fear of the authority? Then do what is good, and you will receive its approval,
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is God’s agent for your good. But if you do what is wrong, you should be afraid, for the authority does not bear the sword in vain! It is the agent of God to execute wrath on the wrongdoer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore one must be subject, not only because of wrath but also because of conscience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the same reason you also pay taxes, for the authorities are God’s agents, busy with this very thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay to all what is due them: taxes to whom taxes are due, revenue to whom revenue is due, respect to whom respect is due, honor to whom honor is due.
speaker: Narrator

text: Owe no one anything, except to love one another, for the one who loves another has fulfilled the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The commandments, “You shall not commit adultery; you shall not murder; you shall not steal; you shall not covet,” and any other commandment, are summed up in this word, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Love does no wrong to a neighbor; therefore, love is the fulfilling of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides this, you know what time it is, how it is already the moment for you to wake from sleep. For salvation is nearer to us now than when we became believers;
speaker: Narrator

text: the night is far gone; the day is near. Let us then throw off the works of darkness and put on the armor of light;
speaker: Narrator

text: let us walk decently as in the day, not in reveling and drunkenness, not in illicit sex and licentiousness, not in quarreling and jealousy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh, to gratify its desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Welcome those who are weak in faith but not for the purpose of quarreling over opinions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some believe in eating anything, while the weak eat only vegetables.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat must not despise those who abstain, and those who abstain must not pass judgment on those who eat, for God has welcomed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who are you to pass judgment on slaves of another? It is before their own lord that they stand or fall. And they will be upheld, for the Lord is able to make them stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some judge one day to be better than another, while others judge all days to be alike. Let all be fully convinced in their own minds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who observe the day, observe it for the Lord. Also those who eat, eat for the Lord, since they give thanks to God, while those who abstain, abstain for the Lord and give thanks to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we do not live to ourselves, and we do not die to ourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we live, we live to the Lord, and if we die, we die to the Lord; so then, whether we live or whether we die, we are the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: For to this end Christ died and lived again, so that he might be Lord of both the dead and the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you pass judgment on your brother or sister? Or you, why do you despise your brother or sister? For we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is written,
“As I live, says the Lord, every knee shall bow to me,
    and every tongue shall give praise to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, each one of us will be held accountable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us therefore no longer pass judgment on one another, but resolve instead never to put a stumbling block or hindrance in the way of a brother or sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know and am persuaded in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself, but it is unclean for anyone who considers it unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your brother or sister is distressed by what you eat, you are no longer walking in love. Do not let what you eat cause the ruin of one for whom Christ died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do not let your good be slandered.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the kingdom of God is not food and drink but righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who serves Christ in this way is acceptable to God and has human approval.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us then pursue what makes for peace and for mutual upbuilding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not, for the sake of food, destroy the work of God. Everything is indeed clean, but it is wrong to make someone stumble by what you eat;
speaker: Narrator

text: it is good not to eat meat or drink wine or do anything that makes your brother or sister stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hold the conviction that you have as your own before God. Blessed are those who do not condemn themselves because of what they approve.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who have doubts are condemned if they eat because they do not act from faith, for whatever does not proceed from faith is sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: We who are strong ought to put up with the failings of the weak and not to please ourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of us must please our neighbor for the good purpose of building up the neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ did not please himself, but, as it is written, “The insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For whatever was written in former days was written for our instruction, so that by steadfastness and by the encouragement of the scriptures we might have hope.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the God of steadfastness and encouragement grant you to live in harmony with one another, in accordance with Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that together you may with one voice glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Welcome one another, therefore, just as Christ has welcomed you, for the glory of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you that Christ has become a servant of the circumcised on behalf of the truth of God in order that he might confirm the promises given to the ancestors
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
and again he says,
“Rejoice, O gentiles, with his people”;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
and again Isaiah says,
“The root of Jesse shall come,
    the one who rises to rule the gentiles;
in him the gentiles shall hope.”
speaker: Narrator

text: May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself feel confident about you, my brothers and sisters, that you yourselves are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, on some points I have written to you rather boldly by way of reminder, because of the grace given me by God
speaker: Narrator

text: to be a minister of Christ Jesus to the gentiles in the priestly service of the gospel of God, so that the offering of the gentiles may be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Christ Jesus, then, I have reason to boast of my work for God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will not be so bold as to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me to win obedience from the gentiles, by word and deed,
speaker: Narrator

text: by the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit, so that from Jerusalem and as far around as Illyricum I have fully proclaimed the gospel of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus I make it my ambition to proclaim the gospel, not where Christ has already been named, so that I do not build on someone else’s foundation,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but as it is written,
“Those who have never been told of him shall see,
    and those who have never heard of him shall understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the reason that I have so often been hindered from coming to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, with no further place for me in these regions, I desire, as I have for many years, to come to you
speaker: Narrator

text: when I go to Spain. For I do hope to see you on my journey and to be sent on by you, once I have enjoyed your company for a little while.
speaker: Narrator

text: At present, however, I am going to Jerusalem in a ministry to the saints,
speaker: Narrator

text: for Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to share their resources with the poor among the saints at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were pleased to do this, and indeed they owe it to them, for if the gentiles have come to share in their spiritual blessings, they ought also to be of service to them in material things.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, when I have completed this and have delivered to them what has been collected, I will set out by way of you to Spain,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I know that when I come to you I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeal to you, brothers and sisters, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to join me in earnest prayer to God on my behalf,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I may be rescued from the unbelievers in Judea and that my ministry to Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed in your company.
speaker: Narrator

text: The God of peace be with all of you. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, a deacon of the church at Cenchreae,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may welcome her in the Lord, as is fitting for the saints, and help her in whatever she may require from you, for she has been a benefactor of many and of myself as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my coworkers in Christ Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: who risked their necks for my life, to whom not only I give thanks but also all the churches of the gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet also the church in their house. Greet my beloved Epaenetus, who was the first convert in Asia for Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Mary, who has worked very hard for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my fellow Israelites who were in prison with me; they are prominent among the apostles, and they were in Christ before I was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Ampliatus, my beloved in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Urbanus, our coworker in Christ, and my beloved Stachys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Apelles, who is approved in Christ. Greet those who belong to the family of Aristobulus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet my fellow Israelite Herodion. Greet those in the Lord who belong to the family of Narcissus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet those workers in the Lord, Tryphaena and Tryphosa. Greet the beloved Persis, who has worked hard in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Rufus, chosen in the Lord, and greet his mother—a mother to me also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers and sisters who are with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet Philologus, Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I urge you, brothers and sisters, to keep an eye on those who create dissensions and hindrances, in opposition to the teaching that you have learned; avoid them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For such people do not serve our Lord Christ but their own appetites, and by smooth talk and flattery they deceive the hearts of the simple-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your obedience is known to all; therefore, I rejoice over you, but I want you to be wise in what is good and guileless in what is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The God of peace will shortly crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timothy, my coworker, greets you; so do Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my fellow Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: I Tertius, the writer of this letter, greet you in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaius, who is host to me and to the whole church, greets you. Erastus, the city treasurer, and our brother Quartus greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now to God who is able to strengthen you according to my gospel and the proclamation of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery that was kept secret for long ages
speaker: Narrator

text: but is now disclosed and through the prophetic writings is made known to all the gentiles, according to the command of the eternal God, to bring about the obedience of faith—
speaker: Narrator

text: to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, to whom be the glory forever! Amen.
speaker: Narrator
